**Jane Darwell** (born **Patti Woodard** , October 15, 1879 – August 13, 1967)
was an American [actress](/wiki/Actress "Actress") of
[stage](/wiki/Stage_\(theatre\) "Stage \(theatre\)"), [film](/wiki/Film
"Film"), and [television](/wiki/Television_film "Television film").[1] With
appearances in more than one hundred major motion pictures spanning half a
century, Darwell is perhaps best-remembered for her poignant portrayal of the
matriarch and leader of the Joad family in the film adaptation of [John
Steinbeck](/wiki/John_Steinbeck "John Steinbeck")'s _[The Grapes of
Wrath](/wiki/The_Grapes_of_Wrath_\(film\) "The Grapes of Wrath \(film\)")_ ,
for which she received the [Academy Award for Best Supporting
Actress](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Supporting_Actress "Academy Award for
Best Supporting Actress"), and her role as the Bird Woman in Disney's musical
family film, _[Mary Poppins](/wiki/Mary_Poppins_\(film\) "Mary Poppins
\(film\)")_. Darwell has a star on the [Hollywood Walk of
Fame](/wiki/Hollywood_Walk_of_Fame "Hollywood Walk of Fame").

## Early life[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Jane_Darwell&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Early life")]

Born to William Robert Woodard, president of the [Louisville Southern
Railroad](/wiki/Louisville_Southern_Railroad "Louisville Southern Railroad"),
and Ellen Booth in [Palmyra](/wiki/Palmyra,_Missouri "Palmyra, Missouri") in
[Marion County](/wiki/Marion_County,_Missouri "Marion County, Missouri") in
northeastern [Missouri](/wiki/Missouri "Missouri"), she originally intended to
become a circus rider, then later an [opera singer](/wiki/Opera_singer "Opera
singer"). Her father objected, however, and she compromised by becoming an
actress but changed her name to _Darwell_ to avoid sullying the family
name.[2]

The [Jane Darwell Birthplace](/wiki/Walker-Woodward-Schaffer_House "Walker-
Woodward-Schaffer House") was added to the [National Register of Historic
Places](/wiki/National_Register_of_Historic_Places "National Register of
Historic Places") in 1984.[3]

### Woodard vs.
Woodward[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Jane_Darwell&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Woodard vs. Woodward")]

Some sources give Darwell's birth name as **Patti Woodward**. They include
_Women in World History: A Biographical Encyclopedia_ ,[4] _Screen World
Presents the Encyclopedia of Hollywood Film Actors: From the silent era to
1965_ ,[5] _Missouri Biographical Dictionary_ ,[6] _Screen World 1968_ ,[7]
_The New Biographical Dictionary of Film_ ,[8] and _Dictionary of Missouri
Biography_.[9]

## Career[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Jane_Darwell&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Career")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/Jane_Darwell_1945.JPG/220px-
Jane_Darwell_1945.JPG)](/wiki/File:Jane_Darwell_1945.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Jane_Darwell_1945.JPG "Enlarge")

Darwell in the play _A Doll 's House_, 1945.

She took up voice culture and the piano followed by a course in dramatics. At
one point, she decided to enter a convent but instead changed her mind and
became an actress. Darwell began acting in theater productions in
[Chicago](/wiki/Chicago,_Illinois "Chicago, Illinois") and made her first film
appearance in 1913. She appeared in almost twenty films over the next two
years before returning to the stage. After a 15-year absence from films, she
resumed her film career in 1930 with a role in _[Tom
Sawyer](/wiki/Tom_Sawyer_\(1930_film\) "Tom Sawyer \(1930 film\)")_ , and her
career as a [Hollywood](/wiki/Hollywood "Hollywood") character actress began.
Short, stout, and plain, she was quickly cast in a succession of films usually
as the mother of one of the major characters. She also appeared in five
[Shirley Temple](/wiki/Shirley_Temple "Shirley Temple") films, usually as the
housekeeper or grandmother.[2]

She won an [Academy Award for Best Supporting
Actress](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Supporting_Actress "Academy Award for
Best Supporting Actress") as "Ma Joad" in _[The Grapes of
Wrath](/wiki/The_Grapes_of_Wrath_\(film\) "The Grapes of Wrath \(film\)")_
(1940), a role she was given at the insistence of the film's star, [Henry
Fonda](/wiki/Henry_Fonda "Henry Fonda"). A contract player with [20th Century
Fox](/wiki/20th_Century_Fox "20th Century Fox"), Darwell was memorably cast in
_[The Ox-Bow Incident](/wiki/The_Ox-Bow_Incident "The Ox-Bow Incident")_ , and
occasionally starred in ["B" movies](/wiki/B_movie "B movie") and played
featured parts in scores of major films.

Darwell had noted appearances on the stage as well; in 1944, she was popular
in the stage comedy _Suds in Your Eye_ , in which she played an Irishwoman who
had inherited a junkyard.[2]

By the end of her career she had appeared in more than 170 films, including
_[Huckleberry Finn](/wiki/Huckleberry_Finn_\(1931_film\) "Huckleberry Finn
\(1931 film\)")_ (1931), _[Jesse James](/wiki/Jesse_James_\(1939_film\) "Jesse
James \(1939 film\)")_ (1939), _[Gone with the
Wind](/wiki/Gone_with_the_Wind_\(film\) "Gone with the Wind \(film\)")_
(1939), _[The Devil and Daniel
Webster](/wiki/The_Devil_and_Daniel_Webster_\(film\) "The Devil and Daniel
Webster \(film\)")_ (1941), _[The Ox-Bow Incident](/wiki/The_Ox-Bow_Incident
"The Ox-Bow Incident")_ (1943), and _[My Darling
Clementine](/wiki/My_Darling_Clementine "My Darling Clementine")_ (1946).[10]

Darwell was among the guest stars on an episode of _[Faye Emerson's Wonderful
Town](/wiki/Faye_Emerson%27s_Wonderful_Town "Faye Emerson's Wonderful Town")_,
a [variety](/wiki/Variety_show "Variety show") [television
series](/wiki/Television_series "Television series") which aired on CBS from
1951 to 1952 in which hostess [Faye Emerson](/wiki/Faye_Emerson "Faye
Emerson") visits a different city each week to accent the local music. In
1954, Darwell appeared with [Andy Clyde](/wiki/Andy_Clyde "Andy Clyde") in the
episode "Santa's Old Suit" of the series, _[The Pepsi-Cola
Playhouse](/wiki/The_Pepsi-Cola_Playhouse "The Pepsi-Cola Playhouse")_. This
same episode was re-run the following Christmas 1955 on _[Studio
57](/wiki/Studio_57 "Studio 57")_. In 1959, she appeared with child actor
[Roger Mobley](/wiki/Roger_Mobley "Roger Mobley") in the episode "Mr. Rush's
Secretary" on the [NBC](/wiki/NBC "NBC") [western](/wiki/Western_\(genre\)
"Western \(genre\)") series, _[Buckskin](/wiki/Buckskin_\(TV_series\)
"Buckskin \(TV series\)")_ , starring [Tom Nolan](/wiki/Tom_Nolan_\(actor\)
"Tom Nolan \(actor\)") and [Sally Brophy](/wiki/Sally_Brophy "Sally Brophy").
She guest starred on [John Bromfield](/wiki/John_Bromfield "John Bromfield")'s
crime drama in a modern western setting, _[Sheriff of
Cochise](/wiki/Sheriff_of_Cochise "Sheriff of Cochise")_.

On July 27, 1961, Darwell appeared as "Grandmother McCoy" in an episode of the
[ABC](/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company "American Broadcasting Company")
[sitcom](/wiki/Sitcom "Sitcom") _[The Real McCoys](/wiki/The_Real_McCoys "The
Real McCoys")_. In the story line, the series characters played by [Walter
Brennan](/wiki/Walter_Brennan "Walter Brennan"), [Richard
Crenna](/wiki/Richard_Crenna "Richard Crenna"), and [Kathleen
Nolan](/wiki/Kathleen_Nolan "Kathleen Nolan") return to fictitious Smokey
Corners, [West Virginia](/wiki/West_Virginia "West Virginia") for Grandmother
McCoy's 100th birthday gathering. Darwell was fifteen years older than "son",
Walter Brennan. [Pat Buttram](/wiki/Pat_Buttram "Pat Buttram") and [Henry
Jones](/wiki/Henry_Jones_\(actor\) "Henry Jones \(actor\)") appeared in this
episode as Cousin Carl and Jed McCoy, respectively.

Darwell's final role as the old woman feeding the birds in _[Mary
Poppins](/wiki/Mary_Poppins_\(film\) "Mary Poppins \(film\)")_ (1964) was
personally assigned to her by [Walt Disney](/wiki/Walt_Disney "Walt
Disney").[10]

On February 8, 1960, Darwell received a star on the [Hollywood Walk of
Fame](/wiki/Hollywood_Walk_of_Fame "Hollywood Walk of Fame") for her
contributions to the motion-picture industry; it is located at 6735 [Hollywood
Boulevard](/wiki/Hollywood_Boulevard "Hollywood Boulevard").[11][12]

In her last years, Darwell's health was poor. It took personal persuasion from
Walt Disney for her to appear in [Disney](/wiki/The_Walt_Disney_Company "The
Walt Disney Company")'s _Mary Poppins_ as she was, by then, tired, frail and
in her middle eighties.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Darwell died August 13, 1967, at the [Motion Picture & Television Country
House and
Hospital](/wiki/Motion_Picture_%26_Television_Country_House_and_Hospital
"Motion Picture & Television Country House and Hospital") in [Woodland
Hills](/wiki/Woodland_Hills,_Los_Angeles "Woodland Hills, Los Angeles"), from
a [myocardial infarction](/wiki/Myocardial_infarction "Myocardial infarction")
at the age of 87.[2] She is interred at [Forest Lawn Memorial
Park](/wiki/Forest_Lawn_Memorial_Park_\(Glendale\) "Forest Lawn Memorial Park
\(Glendale\)") in [Glendale, California](/wiki/Glendale,_California "Glendale,
California").
